translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Elder Nigrodhakappa (Vangīsa)
Thus have I heard:

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā āḷaviyaṁ viharati aggāḷave cetiye.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā āḷaviyam viharati aggāḷave cetiye
translated: At one time the Blessed One was staying at Āḷavī at the Aggāḷava Shrine.

original: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato vaṅgīsassa upajjhāyo nigrodhakappo nāma thero aggāḷave cetiye aciraparinibbuto hoti.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena āyasmataḥ vaṅgīsassa upajjhāyaḥ nigrodhakappaḥ nāma theraḥ aggāḷave cetiye acira parinibbutaḥ hoti
translated: Now at that time the elder named Nigrodhakappa, the preceptor of the venerable Vangīsa, had recently passed away.

original: Atha kho āyasmato vaṅgīsassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
analyzed: atha kho āyasmataḥ vaṅgīsassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evam cetasaḥ parivitakkaḥ udapādi
translated: Then, while the venerable Vangīsa was alone in meditation, the thought arose in his mind:

original: parinibbuto nu kho me upajjhāyo udāhu no parinibbutoti?
analyzed: parinibbutaḥ nu kho me upajjhāyaḥ udāhu no parinibbutaḥ ti
translated: “Has my preceptor attained Nibbāna or not?”

original: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami;
analyzed: atha kho āyasmai vaṅgīsaḥ sāyanha samayam paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami
translated: Then, in the evening, the venerable Vangīsa rose from meditation, went to the Blessed One,

original: upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmā
translated: and after paying homage to him, sat down at one side.
The Blessed One then said to him:

original: idha mayhaṁ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi—
analyzed: idha bhante rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evam cetasaḥ parivitakkaḥ udapādi
translated: “Here, while you were alone in meditation, Vangīsa, the thought arose in your mind:

original: parinibbuto nu kho me upajjhāyo, udāhu no parinibbutoti.
analyzed: parinibbutaḥ nu kho me upajjhāyaḥ udāhu no parinibbutaḥ ti
translated: ‘Has my preceptor attained final Nibbāna, or not?’

original: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīsaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā ekasam cīvaram katvā yena bhagavā tena añjalim paṇāmetvā bhagavantam gāthāya ajjhabhāsi
translated: Then the venerable Vaṅgīsa rose from his seat, and after arranging his robe over one shoulder, he extended his hands in reverential salutation towards the Blessed One and addressed him in verse:
“I ask the Teacher, whose wisdom is sublime,

analyzed: diṭṭhā iva dhamme yaḥ vicikicchānam chettā
translated: Who cuts off the doubts of those in training and those beyond training,
Whether the monk Aggidatta, who had great eloquence,
Renowned and well-known, has attained final Nibbāna.
His name was Nigrodhakappa,
And you, Blessed One, were his teacher.

analyzed: saḥ tam namassam acari muti apekkhaḥ
translated: He went about paying homage to you, looking for release,
Energetic, with insight into the Dhamma.

original: Taṁ sāvakaṁ sakya mayampi sabbe,🔽Aññātumicchāma samantacakkhu;
analyzed: tam sāvakam sakya mayampi sabbe  aññātum icchāma samanta cakkhu
translated: We all wish to know, all-seeing one,🔽About that disciple of yours.
We have assembled to hear,

analyzed: tuvam naḥ satthā tvam anuttarā asi
translated: You are our Teacher, unsurpassed.

original: Chindeva no vicikicchaṁ brūhi metaṁ,🔽Parinibbutaṁ vedaya bhūripañña;
analyzed: chindeva naḥ vicikiccham brūhi mā ita  parinibbutam vedaya bhūri pañña
translated: Cut off our doubt, tell us this,🔽O you of great wisdom, tell us whether he has attained final Nibbāna.

analyzed: majjhā iva naḥ bhāsa samanta cakkhu
translated: Speak to us, all-seeing one,
Just as Sakka, the thousand-eyed one, spoke to the gods.

analyzed: ye keci ganthāḥ idha moha maggā
translated: Whatever knots there are here, paths to delusion,
Wings of ignorance, places of doubt,
When they meet the Realised One, they do not exist,
For this is the supreme eye of men.

original: No ce hi jātu puriso kilese,
analyzed: no ce hi jātu purisaḥ kilese
translated: If a person does not (overcome) the defilements,
Like a wind (blowing through) a forest,
The whole world would be covered in darkness,
Even the radiant one would not shine among men.
But the wise are the illuminators,

original: Taṁ taṁ ahaṁ vīra tatheva maññe;
analyzed: tam tam aham vīra tathā iva maññe
translated: I think it is just so, O Hero,
We have come to Vipassī, the Knower,

original: Parisāsu no āvikarohi kappaṁ.🔽Khippaṁ giraṁ eraya vaggu vagguṁ,
analyzed: parisāsu naḥ āvikarohi kappa  khippam giram eraya vaggu vaggu
translated: Please explain the matter to the assembly.🔽Quickly utter a speech that is lovely, lovely,
Like a goose stretching out and cooing softly,
With a drop of nectar well-prepared,
We all listen with attention.
Having abandoned birth and death without remainder,
I will teach the Dhamma, having discerned the pure state;
For the actions of ordinary people are not done out of desire,

analyzed: ca tathāgatāna  sampanna veyyākaraṇam tava īda
translated: But the actions of the Realised Ones are done with a purpose.🔽This is your complete explanation,
Well-received by one with clear understanding,
This is my last reverential salutation,
Do not deceive me, O you who are wise and have a mind free from delusion.
Having known the supreme and excellent noble Dhamma,

analyzed: mā mohayī jāna manaḥ ma vīra
translated: Do not deceive me, O you who are wise and have a mind free from delusion;
Just as one skilled in water would cross a river,

analyzed: vācā abhikaṅkhāmi sutam pavassa  yadatthikam brahmacariyam acarī
translated: I desire to hear the rain of your words.🔽For the sake of what purpose did you live the holy life?
Was it not in vain for Kappa?
Did he attain Nibbāna right then with residual attachment,
Or was he liberated? We wish to hear this”.
“He cut off craving right here for name-and-form,
(Thus said the Blessed One)
The black stream that had lain dormant for a long time;
He completely crossed over birth and death”,
Thus spoke the Blessed One, the best of the five.
“Having heard this, I am confident,
In your words, O best of sages;
It seems my question was not in vain,
The brahmin does not deceive me.
As he spoke, so he acted,
He was a disciple of the Buddha;
He cut through the net of death,
The firm and deceptive one.
The Blessed One saw the beginning,🔽The suitable one for clinging;
Kappa has indeed gone beyond,
The realm of Death is hard to overcome.”
The Discussion with Nigrodha is the twelfth.
